reviewText: PLOT: The film begins in 1974. A woman is melting wax to put onto some sort of a face mask. She starts saying some nice things to a little boy eating Cheerios while sitting in a high chair. Suddenly her husband comes into the kitchen with another boy kicking and screaming. He restrains the child in a high chair with leather wrist restraints. The screaming child kicks the table and causes the wax mask to fall and break. The mother asks the child why he can't behave like his brother and then smacks him across the face. The film then jumps to 2005. A group of college age friends are on a road trip to see a college football game in Louisiana. The group consists of Carly Jones (Elisha Cuthbert), her brother Nick Jones (Chad Michael Murray), Carly's boyfriend Wade (Jared Padalecki), Dalton Chapman (Jon Abrahams), Blake (Robert Ri'Chard), and Blake's girlfriend Paige Edwards (Paris Hilton). One night the group stops at a camp site and they begin to notice a horrible smell coming from somewhere in the surrounding woods. A mysterious truck later appears and one of the boys throws a beer bottle at it, smashing one of the headlights. The truck then proceeds to drive away. The next morning, the group suspect that one of their cars may have been tampered with during the night because the fan belt is broken. Carly explores the surrounding woods and accidentally falls into a pit of deer carcasses. The rest of the group rescue her. This pit is the source of the foul stench that they smelled during the night. Suddenly a truck pulls up to the sight and empties more deer carcasses into the pit. The driver is a creepy redneck guy (Damon Herriman) who collects and dumps roadkill for a living. The group notice a human arm sticking out of the pit, but the roadkill driver pulls it out and reveals it to be a mannequin's arm. The driver offers to give Carly and Wade a ride into the nearby town of Ambrose so they can get a new fan belt for their car. They accept the offer and the rest of the group get in the other vehicle and drive away with hopes of getting to the football game on time. The driver drop off Carly and Wade at the town's edge. All of the businesses seem to be closed and the streets are deserted. Carly and Wade go to the town church and accidentally interrupt a funeral service. They leave and a man named Bo (Brain Van Holt) comes out of the church and reprimands them for their intrusion. The couple apologize and Bo tells them that he is the gas station worker and that he will help them in a half hour. While waiting, Carly and Wade start exploring the small town and they are drawn to Trudy's House of Wax. They notice that the building itself is made of wax. They go inside and see that it is filled with amazingly life-like figures, but they are all figures of unfamiliar people rather than celebrities or historical figures. Carly notices that all the pieces of wax-work are signed by someone named "Vincent." She then notices in a mirror hanging on the wall that someone was spying on them through the window. The couple soon find out that something is seriously wrong in the town of Ambrose.COMMENTS: Being a huge fan of the 1953 Vincent Price classic, I had to give this remake a gander. Aside from the title, this film basically has nothing to do with the 1953 film or the original 1933 film Mystery Of The Wax Museum. The filmmakers basically took the essence of the original storyline and combined it with The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (1974). The killer is very much a copy of Leatherface except with a mask made of wax instead of human skin; I guess we can refer to him as Waxface. It seems to me that Waxface has a strong physical resemblence to Dream Theater lead singer James LaBrie. The acting of the film is typical slasher horror acting; i.e. the damsel in distress is running up the stairs instead of running out the door, etc. There is nothing original about this film at all. If you like slasher films then this is the film for you. It has it all: extreme gore, bad acting, rednecks, extreme gore, gratuitous sexual content, cheap surprises, did I mention extreme gore. The only thing it doesn't have is gratuitous nudity; sorry guys. I'd have to say that the best thing about this film is the gorgeous Elisha Cuthbert of The Girl Next Door fame; that and Paris Hilton getting a sharp metal spike thrown through her head. I laughed like hell when I saw that scene. This DVD features the film in the original theatrical widescreen format. It also contains B-roll and bloopers video cast commentary, a few behind-the-scenes documentaries, an altermate opening, gag reel, and the theatrical trailer

reviewText: Ignore the extreme comments about "House of Wax", in no way is it either great or totally awful. Many who saw it based on the trailer feel cheated. The trailer makes this movie look very promising, which is what trailers are supposed to do. There is only one thing for sure with trailers, if the producers can't cobble together a minute of interesting elements to make a trailer, it is a pretty much a sure thing that the movie is a major suck-fest. But a good trailer only tells you that a few things about the movie are good, it does not give you much idea about the total package. Here a little research can be valuable."House of Wax" stars Elisha Cuthbert (whose acting skills are closer to Kathy Ireland than to either her fellow Canadian Sarah Polley or her lookalike Rose McGowen), and was directed by a music video artist formerly known as Jaume, in his feature debut. These are not good signs but if you are like me you ignore them and go to see the work of Production Designer Grace Walken, who was responsible for the look of "Ghost Ship". Once again Walken's work is worth seeing, so much so that it looks like 90% of the movie's $30 million budget went to production design. The rest went to Cuthbert to compensate her for the abuse she has to take throughout the film (finger cut off, lips glued shut, tied up, and lots of wading around in assorted gooey stuff). By-the-bye, Cuthbert looks considerably heavier than she did in "The Girl Next Door", about one big pig-out away from having a major weight problem.Which means they had nothing left over to pay the rest of the cast and crew. And judging from the what was on the screen, this might actually be true. It looks like everyone else donated their time to get their first acting or crew credit. Unfortunately, whether it was inexperience or jealousy over the pay disparity, the contributions of all these inexperienced/incompetent volunteers amount to less than zero.Inexperienced Steven Window's DP work was about as awful as you are likely to see and working in league with incompetent editor Joel Negran (insert "Pearl Harbor" here) they manage to take away most of the value added by the production design group. Rather than linger over and showcase the sets, Window filmed this stuff with bad lighting and jerky-zooming-bobbing camera work. Negran compounded the problem with an insane number of disorienting cuts. Poor lighting, an ADD-like camera, and flurry cutting are what you use to hide cheap and crappy production design; not what is needed when the movie's only strength is its expensive and detailed sets.Chan Hayes did the screenplay and Charles Belden (who wrote the original story) is credited as the writer although except for the title and the use of wax figures there is absolutely no similarity. One saving grace is that the movie does not take itself seriously as a horror film and is mostly parody (insert "Van Helsing" here). The murders are played for laughs, too extreme to be scary or even creepy to anyone over age six. The audience particularly cracked up when a certain high profile hotel heiress got her homely face run through by an steel bar, although her earlier half-baked striptease was the only genuinely creepy thing in the film. Another comedy highlight was when Cuthbert sticks her finger through a grate and has it clipped off by the bad guy.The good scenes take place in Trudy's House of Wax, a waxworks that has something to do with a closed sugar mill, conjoined twins, and a lot of roadkill (which Cuthbert gets to bathe in). All this is supposed to be happening somewhere in rural Florida although from the many hills it sure looks like southern California (attention location scouts-the gulf coast is not noted for it's rolling terrain). The screenplay apparently intended to play up the connection (bad pun) between the two sets of twins, but somewhere during production or post-production most of the dialogue concerning this was trimmed. Since what is left about the twin connection makes no sense and goes nowhere, you wonder why it wasn't also cut to reduce the boredom factor.What is particularly sad is that the producers did not have the brains to recognize in mid-production that they had the ingredients for a first rate horror classic-even with the existing cast. What was staring them in the face was a chance to go somewhere with the illusion of a town of wax. Because it is a photographic medium, modern film is intrinsically naturalistic, almost without exception prone to creating an illusion of reality. Here they had a ready-made opportunity to give the photographic medium a theatrical element of extreme stylization. Like an impressionist painting, the town creates the illusion of reality from a distance but reveals itself as a highly stylized wax fabrication up close. Of course they would have had to find a visionary Director and DP to bring the thing off successfully, but everything else was already in place for this to happen.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

reviewText: House of Wax (Jaume Collet-Serra, 2005)I had assumed this movie would suck simply because it was a Paris Hilton vehicle. (And it really was a Paris Hilton vehicle; the cast was built around Hilton.) Then I rented it, and the first thing I see is the "Dark Castle Entertainment" logo. I thought they'd gotten away from doing horrible remakes. Not so, I guess.Collet-Serra's feature film debut follows the Dark Castle formula closely: gather a bunch of young-and-beautifuls, make them act far below their average standard, and blow most of the special effects budget on one really cool effect that people will be talking about incessantly.In this case, the young-and-beautifuls number six. There are Wade (Gilmore Girls' Jared Padalecki) and his girlfriend Carly (24 star Elisha Cuthbert), who are on the rocks. Carly's in-and-out-of-jail twin brother Nick (One Tree Hill's Chad Michael Murray). Nick's best friend Blake (Robert Ri'chard, last seen in Coach Carter) and his girlfriend Paige (Paris Hilton). And then there's Dalton (Boston Public's Jon Abraham), tagging along for the ride, the annoying kid with the video camera who seems de rigeur in every action thriller since Trespass twelve years ago. They are on their way to a big football game when a shortcut ends up under construction and they have to find a place to camp. They do so about fifteen miles from a small town called Ambrose (which, while judging by the surrounding dialogue would seem to be in Louisiana, sports inhabitants with a marked lack of southern accents). The six of them have a strange run-in with a mysterious pickup truck, go to sleep (without, it should be noted, posting a watch), and wake up to find the fan belt on Wade's car has broken. Wade and Carly stay behind to go into Ambrose and get a new fan belt, while the others continue on to the game. Once in Ambrose, Wade and Carly meet Bo (Threshold's Brian van Holt), the owner of the local gas station, who doesn't have a fan belt at the station, but there might be one in the delivery up at the house...To give you a plot summary that doesn't get to spoilerville would take well beyond a thousand words itself. Its odd how, when everything in a movie is so completely trivial, it all seems to reach the same level of unimportance, eventually. (I will tell you this, though: Paris Hilton dies on page 596.)House of Wax suffers from the same problems as, well, every one of Dark Castle's other flicks to date. The young-and-beautifuls are recruited, mostly, from TV primetime soap operas, and therefore are used to the kind of overemoting that Dark Castle's higher-ups seem to find an acceptable substitute for actual acting. (It should be noted, however, that when he's not being overly dramatic, the best performance in the film by a country mile is turned in by Murray; the only other performance in the film even close is that of Lester [Son of the Mask and They's Damon Harriman], whose part is small, but effective.) The script is threadbare to say the least, having thoroughly jettisoned everything about the original House of Wax and replaced it with a kind of Texas Chainsaw Massacre vibe that might actually be halfway effective if, well, someone hadn't already remade Texas Chainsaw Massacre last year. And done it a whole lot better than this.Its strengths are fewer, but again, they cling to the Dark Castle mold. The everpresent "one really cool special effect" really is cool; the house of wax is completely made of wax. Which leads to all sorts of nifty melting stuff. You've all seen the "guy running with path crumbling behind him" thing before? Yeah, but they do it in a kind of novel way here. And, like all Dark Castle films, the movie is inherently watchable, partly because it's so bad that you want to see what happens next, partly because Dark Castle's writing stable seems to have been culled from the ranks of soap opera writers; they know what to do, and how to do it badly. Also-- and this did come as a pleasant surprise-- Dark Castle broke the "seeing the monster too much" mold here. The monster gets so little exposure that, for a second, I almost felt like I was watching a movie made before Friday the 13th. That quickly wore off when I realized that not a single major character in this movie was born when the original Friday the 13th came out. **

reviewText: Fans of the horror genre, who tend to like life a little goopier than the staid crowd, will be sure to enjoy this B-Movie romp through squishy redneck woods and thick, waxy floors.This film is not close to being a remake of the original House of Wax, nor is it very original in such a large bin of teen-slasher flicks, but it does hold its own in the sea of bloody, mucky thrills-for-rent.  The plot manages to save itself from being too typical by actually having a semi-lucid reason for the teen's woodsy frolics, and by avoiding the pitfalls of who will obviously be the first victim.The performances are not spectacular, but the characters are shallow enough not to require great skills from the actors.  The good parts of the movie is the photography and the FX, providing us with a unique squish of wax in that oozing place that satisfies us horror fans.A group of teens camp out on their way to try and grab tickets for a game.  A spooky encounter with a faceless truck leaves them with one car needing a fan belt.  Dividing up, two of the kids accept a ride into town with a sleazy redneck.  The town seems quaint but strange, and while waiting for the gas station owner to finish up with a funeral, the kids explore the House Of Wax.Not everything is as it seems though, there's more wax than meets the eye, and more to the wax than you would expect.  You'll never walk past a wax figure without scraping your fingernail over it, that much I promise.The most pleasing aspect of the film is when Paris Hilton 'gets the point' in a satisfyingly grisly scene, but the subplot of the brothers who run the House Of Wax is a pleasingly crunchy idea also.  The waxy FX in the finale is great, better than mud could ever be.  There is also a lovely carcass pit earlier in the film that you can practically smell through your television.All in all, a nice B horror movie to enjoy with lots of popcorn and beer.  Rent before you buy.  Enjoy!

The plot sounds insane, but the movie is actually quite enjoyable, especially if you like films that depict young people being chased by crazed killers. The special effects are intelligent and the performances are strong, headed by "One Tree Hill" hunk Chad Michael Murray. The movie is also known for the screen debut of Paris Hilton, who unlike what the critics say, is actually a good actress. A film clip of Bette Davis from "What Ever Happened To Baby Jane?" is used in the film when the characters come across an old run down theatre. The movie grossed over $68 million at the boxoffice and made another $42 million on DVD so the film was a commercial success. The DVD comes with behind-the-scenes featurettes on the making of the movie, the trailer is included, and an alternate opening comes with the set. "The Long Island Press" says of "The House of Wax" that, it's a "hot, sexy, deliciously creepy horror film".

reviewText: What can you say about a film that stars not only the "American Princess" as she calls herself Paris Hilton but also other stars of WB?  I went into this not expecting too much but I had heard about the awesome climax involving a melting house and figured that was worth the price of admission alone.  I came out surprised.  It actually is pretty decent.As the slasher horror genre goes, you have young co-eds who, through bad luck, sex etc getting into some trouble that constantly worsens.  Most of the time, the events that occur are because someone is running up the stairs instead of out the door, or going with the crazy hick who dumps roadkill in a disgusting mess on the side of the road and has pelts of animals hanging in his car and a huge knife on his belt.  That said, House of Wax follows the same conventions but normally they give a better reason for the protagonists to follow them than most slasher films.In fact, unlike movies like Scream and Wrong Turn, etc, the movie starts out slowly.  Not boring, not by any means.  But it isn't until at least half way in that someone dies.  In some movies this could be movie suicide as the audience gets bored.  But here, the director allows a sense of foreboding build.  While nothing major happens, there are all these signs that something isn't right and for most of the movie you have a pit in your stomach until the first death and the proverbial crap hits the fan.Honestly, the film isn't that great.  It's not something that transcends the horror genre, nor will it or should it win awards or go down as the best horror movie ever.  But what it does do, it does well: it is pretty scary.  It is also pretty gross.  Overall, if you want to see a good horror movie this season, I would recommend this over some of the others released this year.  Until the French film High Tension (go see that, I totally recommend it having seen a copy from France) comes out on June 10th, this is probably your best bet for a quick scare fix.

reviewText: The plot of House of Wax is hardly anything new or creative.  A group of young, good looking twenty-somethings out on a roadtrip ending up in a backwoods town where a sadistic family preys on them.  We've seen this before in Texas Chainsaw Massacre, House of 1000 Corpses, Wrong Turn, to name just a few.  No, it's not original but what it lacks in originality it more than makes up for in execution.The group of six that includes Carly and her brother Nick (Elisha Cuthbert and Chad Michael Murray) are joined by Carly's boyfriend Wade (Jared Padelecki of TV's Supernatural), Nick's buddy Dalton, and Paige (Paris Hilton) and her boyfriend Blake.  The group are travelling to a football game when Wade's car breaks a fan belt.  Wade and Carly go into town to get a replacement and find the town basically deserted.  People peek out from curtains but the streets are deserted.They interrupt a funeral at a small church and Bo, who owns the town garage offers to help.  While waiting for Bo the pair visit the strange house of wax that has many extremely life-like wax figures but none of them look like anyone famous.  Bo lures them back to the house where the truth is revealed...that he and his brother, the masked Vincent make their creations with real bodies and lure unsuspecting motorists into the ghost town by false detour signs.  One by one the brothers pick off the group with paris Hilton getting the award for most gruesome death in the film.What sets House of Wax apart from others of its ilk is the inventiveness of the House of Wax itself.  The building is completely made of wax...the walls, the floors, the furniture, all wax which leads to a truly awe-inspired climax.  Cuthbert, looking very different with darker hair than she did in "The Girl Next Door" presents a strong female heroine.  Even after having her lips super-glued together and having a finger tip cut off, she fights back with zeal and is the most interesting character in the movie.  Most of the other performances are pretty standard stuff...Nick is the bad boy tough guy, Paige the sex-crazed dumb blonde, Dalton the joking tag-along,etc...A better film than I ever thought it would be!Reviewed by Tim Janson

reviewText: A horror adventure featuring a group of twentysomethings, House Of Wax (2005) bears practically no resemblance to the Vincent Price horror classic from 1953.  Not a remake, director Jaume Collett-Serra's (Unknown, Orphan) film is a demented tale of terror set in a small "forgotten" town.  While not at all credible, and with some pretty annoying victims, the film does have some creepy moments, impressive special effects, and one magnificent kill of a socialite turned actress.With the realism of a Scooby Doo adventure, the film's flimsy premise is that the town of Ambrose has somehow dropped off the map, and been forgotten, although strangely it is somehow still getting power from the local grid, and is wired such that most electrical loads are connected to a bank of circuit breakers located in an underground tunnel.  Now closed, the House Of Wax museum was once Ambrose's main attraction.  The only residents of the town are brothers, one runs the local gas station, while the other is an expert in coating the human body with wax.On their way to see a football game, a group of friends have a little car trouble.  Looking for a replacement part, Carly Jones (Elisha Cuthbert, hot at the time from being on TV's 24) and her boyfriend Wade (Jared Padalecki) arrive in Ambrose, where they meet Bo (Brian Van Holt) the owner of the service station.  The couple is at Bo's home, when things unexpectedly take a nasty turn.What follows isn't credible, but it is rather suspenseful, gory, and kind of fun, as Carly becomes a prisoner in a room below the service station.  What Bo wants isn't clear, but he's apparently into collecting body parts.  Luckily Carly's brother Nick (Chad Michael Murray) arrives in town in the nick of time, and manages to rescue her, but the pair is forced to flee, when Bo opens fire with a shotgun.Looking to add to his collection of waxed corpses, Bo's brother Vincent (Van Holt in a dual role) acts decisively to capture or kill whoever crosses his path.  In one of the film's best scenes, Vincent miraculously manages to find members the group camping in the woods, and brutally disposes of them.  Paige (Paris Hilton) attempts to escape, and even strikes back at Vincent, but is brutally slain in spectacular fashion.Back in Ambrose, the siblings are trapped in Bo's house when Vincent returns with the dead bodies of their friends.  Nick discovers a secret tunnel leading to the museum, and while trying to escape from Vincent, sets fire to the structure, which actually is made of wax.  The scenes of the burning and melting wax structure, with the people struggling to move in the sticky mess, is pretty cool and quite well done.A Dark Castle production shot on location in Australia, House of Wax is shaky like a house of cards, but if you put realism on the back burner, the film is mostly redeemed by the gore and special effects.  It's pretty darn slick in the production and effects departments, concluding with the museum melting down to the ground in a glorious inferno.  Paris Hilton's death scene is a classic (who says she can't act?), and Brian Van Holt is not too bad in a dual role.  There's no commentary track, but the DVD has a couple of fun extras.
summary: some creepy moments, impressive special effects, and one magnificent kill of a socialite turned actress...

reviewText: 'House of Wax,' another horror from Dark Castle Entertainment, which previously produced 'Ghost Ship' 'Gothika' and others, is an average slasher film with generic script.  The film is most likely to be linked to Paris Hilton (who is only fourth-billed), but the real talent behind this film should be Graham 'Grace' Walker, who provided wonderful production designs.  But, story first.The fact is, 'House of Wax' is a remake of Vincent Price classic horror, but in name only.  It is more like a rip-off of 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre,' and as you see, six college students foolishly stray into Southern Nowhereville, where some crazy people are prowling with a bloody knife or something.  The difference from the Tobe Hooper classic is that this time they get to the murderer's house after finding a short-cut by messing around GPS of their car.  Original, isn't it?[NICE PRODUCTION DESIGNS] In spite of pretty boring first-half, however, 'House of Wax' gets into gear when we are introduced to the fictional town of Ambrose, spooky place with an old movie theater (where 'What Ever Happened to Baby Jane' is still showing), and of course, a wax museum.  Though Jaume Collet-Serra did a good job as director, the production designs by Graham Walker is much more impressive than the very gory and painful deaths themselves.I have no objection to the cardboard characters played by Elisha Cuthbert et al, who do silliest things -- 'I go this way, you go that way' kind of thing -- but perhaps we should not talk about it right now.  As to Paris Hilton, she certainly can dance nicely in underwear.  And she even allows for some embarrassing self-parodying (is it so?) by being video-taped while doing what you don't want to know.The film has some scary moments that end with bloody deaths, but real originality comes at the end with a big finale in the wax museum.  Except that, like similar horrors (recent example, 'Wrong Turn') 'House of Wax' is an average slasher horror with a few redeeming points.
summary: Well, I Expected Worse ... Average Slasher with Superb Designs

reviewText: HOUSE OF WAX is a remake of a 1953 picture of the same name that starred Vincent Price.  Having never yet seen the original, I can't comment on comparisons between the two films.  This version of the story was produced by Joel Silver and Robert Zemeckis, among others, and was the feature directorial debut of Jaume Collet-Serra. I was a bit hesitant to watch the movie because the picture was promoted as Paris Hilton's breakout role. In fact, she was the first person cast in the movie and the rest of the cast was built around her.  However, despite my reluctance to originally watch the movie, HOUSE OF WAX is actually a fairly decent slasher-suspense movie.The plot of the movie is fairly simple.  A group of six college-age friends leave together on a roadtrip to see the biggest football game of the year in Louisiana.  They leave the main road to take a shortcut.  The shortcut ends up having a detour and the group camps for the night in a woody field.  That night the group is harassed by a man in a pickup truck.  One of the friends, Nick Jones (Chad Michael Murray), throws a beer bottle at the truck, breaking a headlight which for whatever reason causes the driver to leave.  That night Nick's twin sister, Carly (Elisha Cuthbert), is awaken by noises she hears outside of their tent. She investigates, but doesn't find anything.  However, the next day Carly's boyfriend, Wade (Jared Padalecki) discovers that the fan belt to his car has been cut.  Wade and Carly hitch a ride into a nearby town with a creepy guy who picks up road kill for a living to get a fan belt while the rest of the group leaves to go to the game.  Traffic is so bad that the group misses most of the game and comes back to the campsite. Meanwhile, Wade and Carly find themselves wandering around a dingy looking town that looked like it once was quaint.  The town professes to have a famous wax museum that Wade and Carly investigate. As it turns out, the wax house is literally made of wax as is most everything in it and the figures are so lifelike.  Of course, there's a reason for that as Wade, Carly, and the rest of their friends soon find out.You would think that the worst part of this movie would be Paris Hilton.  That's really not the case.  Her character is very wooden with hardly any emotional depth, but that's exactly how her character is supposed to be.  There's a fair enough amount of suspense and just enough gore to give the film an overall eerie mood.The film has one huge weakness: the stupidity factor.  I realize that horror films in general require a huge suspension of disbelief and almost always have characters doing things very, very stupid. However, in HOUSE OF WAX that seems more prevalent than normal. For instance, take the character of Wade. As an audience member, you're supposed to like Wade. He's Carly's boyfriend and is supposed to be a nice guy, the kind a girl can take home to her parents are ask move to New York with her to begin a new life. Yet, Wade once Wade meets the guy who picks up road kill, he turns rude and abrasive.  I couldn't wait until he got killed because the whole time he was in Ambrose, he was a complete jerk: smarting off to strangers, breaking into closed buildings, searching through people's personnel items.  Or take Paris Hilton's character, Paige.  At one point Paige is being chased by a killer and arms herself with a pole, but eventually leaves the pole behind. Or how about the fact that while wondering around the town the only person anyone ever sees and meets is Bo? I grew up in a town smaller than Ambrose and even late at night your bound to see cars driving around or someone walking around.Overall, despite starring Paris Hilton and filled with bad acting, HOUSE OF WAX is a better-than-expected suspense-slasher movie.The DVD special features include an alternate opening scene, b-roll and blooper video with cast commentary, Joel Silver revealing HOUSE OF WAX (watch Joel get ran over by a car), "Wax On: the Design of the House of Wax" featurette about how the town of Ambrose, Louisiana was created, "The House Built on Wax" featurette about how the actual wax house in HOUSE OF WAX was created, and the theatrical trailer.

reviewText: I saw House of Wax in the theater and after having anticipated its release for several months I found it fairly disappointing.  Not the worst movie ever and although it had its high points it was certainly not the best either.  I left feeling like it could have been so much more; I also felt that it was not truly a remake of House of Wax as it shares almost nothing with the two original films of the same name except its recognizable title.In fact, I seem to be the only person who thinks it was actually meant to be a remake of a 1979 horror flick called "Tourist Trap"--a freaky, scary horror movie that gives me the chills so much that I can really only tolerate watching it once every year or two and only in a fully lit room, with at least one other person present!  This House of Wax has FAR more in common with Tourist Trap than any previous House of Wax film.  I think someone realized what a great and truly creepy movie Tourist Trap is but also understood that it is not one of the more well known horror films and decided to call it House of Wax in order to bank on Vincent Price's name and talents.  Watch the either of the two previous House of Wax movies, then watch Tourist Trap (not recommending you watch that one alone!) then watch this House of Wax and make your own decision...That being said despite my lukewarm feelings for Wax in the theater, which I later chalked up to having had a headache at the time and not being in a very good mood, I did buy it right off the bat once it was released on dvd.  I have seen it so many times now that I can't even count.  Regardless of its shortcomings it has become one of my favorite horror movies to throw on when I fall asleep or as background noise when I am cleaning.  :-)House of Wax just seems to work better on the small screen than it did in the theater.  Good points: casting. Yes, even Ms. Hilton seems to have a place in the film.  I found the characters and actors to be quite believable in their roles and thought they had good chemistry and worked well together.  Are they all the best actors around?  No, but for what the movie is supposed to be I think they fit the bill nicely.Suspense is another good point in the film.  While it does take a bit of time for us to get to any real action (the movie clocks in at approximately 48 minutes before anyone is even attacked and this may be part of the reason a lot of people see it as dull or over-long) once we do arrive it is very suspenseful.  Until the tail end of the story the movie avoids some traditional cliches and actually DOES do some stuff that you don't expect.  In the theater I was saying to myself "Oh they're not gonna do that, no, they're not REALLY gonna do it" but they did--won't tell you what as I don't want to spoil anything.  In the down time that leads up to that 48 minute mark where the movie explodes we do get a lot of very good character development, another point that no one can accuse the movie of falling short on.The visuals are wonderful!  It is pretty amazing the incredible detail and hard work that went into creating this town where the movie takes place, and such work should be acknowledged and appreciated.  I enjoyed the behind the scenes look at creating the buildings and props and so on and I feel like it's a shame the movie didn't do as well as it could have in theaters for the reason alone that so many will miss the great set design and work that went into it.One weak point overall is the music.  The score is very good at certain points and totally ineffective or lacking in others.  For the most part it is adequate but the songs that are played in the movie are terrible and add nothing to the feel or emotion.  A minor complaint!  Towards the end of the movie the dialogue becomes run-of-the-mill and we've heard it all before but I did like the dynamics of the surviving characters.  The one thing that annoys me to no end with this movie is the very last thing they do in it.  Incredibly unnecessary and ridiculous thing to tack on to the end and it nearly ruins some of the story (for me at least).  When rating this movie I usually knock off a full star due to that alone.Overall, with House of Wax you are not going to be in for a mind-blowing experience but you will be in for some great visuals, strong performances, good suspense and a horror movie that is not quite the same as the rest.Just as a side note...for anyone who is not familiar with the movie Tourist Trap, please seek it out and watch it!  Then if you've seen at least one of the two previous House of Wax films as well as TT let me know whether you agree with my comments about the similarities (or please leave comments if you have already seen all of these films).  I am highly interested to hear other opinions on the subject!  Thanks!
summary: Seems more like a remake of "Tourist Trap" than "House of Wax"...

reviewText: Before objecting to my rating a film like this 5-Stars, please hear me out.First of all, this is not a remake of the splendid 1953 Vincent Price cult flick of the same name. The only thing these two films have in common is their title, their genre, and the fact that they both somehow involve a wax museum. For this reason it's a mite pointless to compare the two as they are, in fact, two totally different stories. (Even so, I'm going to do just that at the end of this review).THE STORY: Six college students (4 dudes and 2 gals) drive from Gainesville to Baton Rouge to attend an important football game. Since it's a long trip, they camp out in the woods somewhere off I-10. One of their cars strangely won't run the next day and they discover a mysterious town in the sticks while looking for a fan belt. It is there that they encounter the titular House of Wax. Horror and death ensue.Although the first 10 minutes or so are fairly unimpressive, the story starts to capture your attention at the campout sequence. From there their encounter with a horrible stench, a local hick, and the mystery of the isolated town & wax museum gradually pulls you in. The fairly slow initial 50-minutes are an important character-building and mystery-building foundation to the final horrific hour.The major protagonist of the story is the awe-inspiringly fair Elisha Cuthbert, who was only 22 years old during filming. The eminently glamorous (and infamous) Paris Hilton also stars and does a commendable job, but Elisha utterly blows her out of the water as far as all-around beauty goes.Speaking of Ms. Hilton, [minor Spoiler alert] she does indeed buy the farm in this film and, the way it happens, just made me bust out laughing! The film's worth checking out for this scene alone, especially if you despise her.The picture was shot in Queensland, Australia, of all places, but it works well as a stand-in for the deep South. The filmmaking is top-notch in all categories; even the rest of the no-name cast do a fine job. As a matter of fact, the six college kids are all rather likable, even Nick (Chad Michael Murray), Elisha's supposedly 'black sheep' twin.The story, albeit highly unlikely, is played straight and serious by all involved; there's no silly "comedic relief" or camp to be seen.BOTTOM LINE: So why do I give such a film as this 5-Stars? Simply because "House of Wax" works fabulously for what it IS, a mystery/horror flick. Everyone knows going in that this isn't going to be "Gandhi" (not that I've ever seen that award-winning epic film -- sssnnnnoooorrrreeee). But if you're in the mood for an entertaining, engrossing and imaginative mystery/horror picture, look no further; "House of Wax" has everthing you could possibly want in such a film. Why do I describe it as imaginative? Just wait till you see the conclusion's spectacular melting wax museum and you'll know what I mean; this is F/X at its finest.COMPARISON: Plotwise, "House of Wax" is an obvious mixture of the original "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" (1974) and the 1953 film of the same name. I fully realize that motion pictures must be judged according to the time they were made, their originality (or lack) at that time, and the limitations thereof. But if one were to objectively view both of these movies back-to-back with this modern "House of Wax" and honestly judge which film is better TODAY, (not in 1974, not in 1953, but TODAY), she or he would have no choice but to conclude that this 2005 "House of Wax" blows 'em both out of the water. Cinematic blasphemy? Perhaps. See for yourself and be honest; and don't let nostalgia interfere with your judgment.

reviewText: House of wax is a slasher film, but it's not your typical slasher film. The plot sounds familiar: group of people on a road trip get sidetracked; end up in bizarre, little town; get hunted down like animals. Three things make this film stand out.First, is the setup. This movie takes a long time to get going. About half of the movie goes by before there's any action. The film uses this time to let us become familiarized with the characters. Most horror movies are in such a haste to get to the action, they start killing off characters immediately. House of Wax lets us build at least some interest in these people before attacking them. It also uses this time to display the truly creepy atmosphere of this small town. The first half of this movie really does play like a horror movie from the '50's or '60's. It relies on good characters, mood, and atmosphere to create a disturbing feeling while watching it.Second, is the violence. When the action finally starts, it goes all out. The second half of the move is slasher all the way. This is an incredibly violent movie and the violence is extremely graphic. This movie is right up there with the Texas Chainsaw Massacre remake. There are three parts in particular - one involves super glue, one involves wire cutters, and one involves a baseball bat - that even the most hard core horror fan could not help but appreciate. It might seem uneven, blending '50's and '60's horror with teen-slasher horror, but it really flows well. It's like watching a crack grow in a dam before it explodes.Third, is the ending. The climax of this film is amazing. The setting is an absolute work of art. It takes place as the hero's are trying to escape from a burning building. The walls are melting around them. The ceiling is melting down on top of them. The floor is melting beneath their feet. The only way to escape is to fight their way past two psychotic, serial killers. The killers are armed with knives; the hero's with a baseball bat. How the heroine uses that bat against one of the villains may be the most graphic act of violence I've ever seen in a movie (I challenge you to think of an equal). But, then, you can hardly blame her after what he did to her using the super glue and wire cutters.A great horror film.
summary: Super glue, wire cutters, and a baseball bat. Awsome.

reviewText: I just saw this movie on pay per view the other night, and I thought it was pretty decent, better than I expected to be honest.  Definitely a change from the Vincent Price version of the story, which is fine, because if you aren't going to change anything, why do a remake?  Still, I felt this movie was a bit too much like the Texas Chainsaw Massacre.  A group of kids on a road trip who end up stopping in a small hick town where they run into some redneck weirdos who are hiding a disfigured brother... hmm.  Where have we heard this before?  That's my only real complaint about the movie - the changes to the original story made House of Wax just a wee bit too much like the Texas Chainsaw story.On the other hand, it was a cool idea to have the entire town be made up of nothing but wax covered people who were murdered one by one.  The action & suspense were enough to hold my interest the entire movie (which isn't always easy to do for me), and the acting was respectable considering the fact that this movie stuck with the usual formula of rounding up a bunch of good looking kids to base the story on.  Not a classic - I'll stick with the Vincent Price version - but this newest remake is definitely worth a watch.
summary: Decent, but Texas Chainsaw Massacre anyone?
